												This is for the Classic Loki server. I have not played on the Renewal server.In terms of a decade old MMORPG, Ragnarok really hits home for the nostalgia factor. Gameplay is still smooth and fun. I quite enjoy playing.That said....The botting is rampant, don't bother trying to sell anything through vending. Someone has more on sale for less because bots.War of Emperium is a cycle of 3-4 guilds exchanging castles on a weekly basis. If you want to try and bring a new guild in, be prepared to be squashed by maxed out veterans wearing god-items.The market is beyond skewed. The botters have so much on the market that you are LUCKY if you keep a vigilant eye on sites like ragial.com for good deals, as some poor sap tries to undercut the botters of their excessive amounts of loot.To counter the botters, folks will often crack "dead branches" (spawns high-level mobs) where bots frequent in an attempt to grief kill them. Chances are you will die a few dozen times to these things walking from Prontera to Izlude or just trying to get to your hunting grounds.Logging on, the server is usually at 500+ players. Of that, I suspect 150-200 are vending and about 100 are actual human players. The rest are botting.With the population so low, it does make the game a bit more fun, in terms of not having to fight over mob spawns (unless it is a profitable area with decent returns, in which case you'll be fighting with botters for mobs) and Prontera is, pretty much, the only place one will find Vendors. There are some in Payon, sometimes. Ragial.com's bot only survery's Prontera/Payon, so why vend elsewhere?There are constant "jump" events. Events where people can take their character from lvl 1 to 70 in a day with a few simple quests.Falling outside of the 15 level limit for shared exp in parties will leave you lonely and bored as the rest of your guild refuses to help you catch up because there is no profit for them in it, despite having helped them along...TL;DR, plan to play a solo game and you'll have fun. If you played this back in the day, Classic Loki is, pretty much, exactly the same game you played 10 years ago.Despite all the annoying and frustrating things I listed above, I still like the game. I just wish there were fewer botters. :(

												Can't help but recommend this game. Yes it's old like other people have said but it's graphics were setup in  way so they don't age. Wonderfull 2D sprites in a amazing easy on the eyes 3D world. I've actual played this game since late Alpha, early Beta, about the 1999-2000 time frame. And I still play to this day, though mainly on the classic server.Beside the easy on the eye graphics another amazing feature is the customization you can do with your character's stats and skills. Unlike nearly every other game on the market you stats matter. Your character's ablity will change massively based on what stats you take.Want a Swordsman that dodges attacks and hits faster instead of just taking hits and having high hit points ? Put points in to Agility instead of Vitality. This means you trade High Hitpoints and high defense for High Flee (dodge) and high Attack speed. You then could go on to make a Agility based knight or Crusader with your swordsman. Or go the middle of the ground and do a hybrid of Agility and Vitality, You might not dodge as well as pure agility or have as much hitpoints as pure Vitality but you can take less damage per hits then agility based characters, and dodge more then pure vitality. And this is just the start of it, You can go pure support acolyte forgoing increased melee damage for the ability to heal massive amounts of damage, or for a true acolyte and have a mix of Melee damage and Healing ability. Want a Mage that beats things as well as toss magic at them? Put points into Strength, Vitality, and Agility, instead of going pure intelligence. You lose magic damage but can dodge, take hits, and do better melee damage then a pure magic caster. Go the sage route and get the skills that let you move while casting and add the chance to auto cast a low level bolt spell while your hitting monsters.  Like making money, while beating on things with axes, swords or maces? Go a Merchant class character. They don't have the Melee skills of other classes but you can carry more loot or healing potions items then any other class, can buy cheaper and sell for more then any other classes, have access to a cart to carry even more loot/potions, and use your fortune to pay the god of the merchants to attack your enemies (Mammonite skill). Want to craft potions or weapons, take your Merchant to ether Alchemist or Blacksmith. And even Blacksmith and Alchemist have the ability to go Pure Battle, pure Crafting, or a Middle ground, not building items as well as their pure counter parts but still being able to fight for themselves.And there are many other classes to chose from like Archers, thief, TaeKwon Kid, Ninja, Gunslinger ans Super Novice. On top of all that it's free to play, with subscription players (only 7 bucks a month) only get 50% more experience and loot drops, larger storage and other minor abilities. I've spent most of my time since it's gone free to play not using a subscription (they call it VIP) and had no problems with it. So give it a try, nothing to lose but a lot of your free time, and a lot of fun to be had.edit: fixed some spelling issues

												Lets be clear: I love RO.  My username is a result of my love of RO.  I played on iRO all those years ago, and broke into tears when I hear the Prontera Theme for the first time in years.Thing is, all that love is nothing more than rose tinted glasses now.  This game is old.  REALLY old.Old time Thief players (like me!) will easily understand that much of the combat is literally just "Right Click, AFK"  Sure it gets more involved once you go up against MVPs and play in PvP/WoE, but fact of the matter is that you still have to chew through the leveling to get there.  Fast travel is still "Blow entire newbie fortune on Kafra, or blow entire newbie fortune on FWing spam".  Unless you're a Priest.  There are also really archaic mechanics like how spell channeling is completely cancelled when you take damage; dumb fact, but that's the whole reason why I hate Mages to this day.Thankfully, at least the graphics aged well.  The styalized look somehow managed to hold up for more than a decade, and the game itself could literally run on a toaster.  Also, you don't have to deal with ye olde iRO "Server Connection Failed" shenanigans as often as we used to, nor do you need to deal with a steep grind (by today's standards) due to the questing system...although said system is rather haphazardly cobbled together.If you're an oldie, at least Warp Portal set up a Classic server because you'll be completely lost on the Renewal ones.  Quests are nice, but mob spawn locations and even spawn power were COMPLETELY overhauled.  Simple example: Zombies are now less dangerous than Skeletons.  The level of a Kobold is roughly 3x higher than it used to be.  At least Porings are still Porings...

												I've played RO since 2000, but only discovered that it was in steam a few months ago. The steam version itself is ok... Not the best definately not, but not the worst either. It is a pixel-ish game. So if graphics are a big thing for you, RO is not for you. RO is possibly one of my favorite RPGs of all time. Not just from nostalgia alone, but there are certain decisions Gravity made that was just amazing. Here are some of them:-You don't have to chose your class immediately.  -- it's a small design factor since you do go to a class system, but having the player wait till lvl 10 to get a class makes all     that grinding a bit better. You grind in every RPG, but knowing that that grind can really change your character progression in a more significant way than just a few skills and attributes for your already established class. -Player to player trade is encouraged with the merchant class  -- This is a big factor to me since it gives all that dead space worth something. Most MMORPGs have this grand city, with only 30-40% actually relevant. Having a AH does make trading simpler, but less exciting in my opinion. Since selling your stuff to another player is best with the merchant class, most guilds have at least one, and most players have at least one character that is a merchant, and you kinda do it with a stall in the city street, and since you dont want to be an a$$ the city streets have more purpose than simple pathways. RO is beyond its peak. I can say that out loud, but theres no doubt it is a great MMORPG. I wish  there are more games like RO.

Posted: May 15, 2014
												Overall: 6.5/10Art: 8/10Design: 5/10Graphics: 4/10Sound: 9/10With more than 10 years of history, Ragnarok Online is an old MMORPG game to many. At a quick glance - it may seem fun to you but however, the community of this game really makes up a lot of your in-game experience. Talking about community, this game has real players who gave you the cold shoulders because of the vast amount of bots in the game. Lot's of Philipino and Asian players, you know you could reach out to them and make some friends if you are one of them - and assuming they don't ignore you. They are generally cocky and arrogant, but few handful would still help you out if you are lucky enough to meet them. Noobs start out weak (of course) and without a proper guild, party and friends, its almost impossible to get powerful unless you spend on the game. Well, duh. That's the main purpose.This game has a rich art base and many fans would draw them for fun, laughter, peace and joy. It's a 3D game, and a very successful one during its time - one would not simply ignore the art and just play the game. The art is great in my point of view and I do admit that their art makes me get hooked to the game. You will rave about the awesome sprite of your character, no matter the class you are in.The core design of the game offers you guild wars, Player VS Player, vending, and turn-ins. (for exp) It's a wonderful world out there to explore as well, though you might just go for the shortcut and teleport around the world if you purchase their premium services. With that said, the design is very multiplayer heavy - and you will only gain from it if you play with someone else. There will be events held often in the game, be sure to take advantage of it and not miss it ! Wide diversity of classes, you will always find a class that suits you most. However, some special classes do not offer you rebirths - so you lack some extra stat and skill points which makes you weaker than most players.Graphics is cool. The skills animation are awesome in my opinion and they are truly worth raving about as you scale later on in to the game where you do job advancement for your character. There are items in the game that needs to be purchased in real cash to exchange for better graphical aesthetics. Other than that, the animation might be a little choppy due to the latency of the game - it depends on where you are from and all.Sound. The reason why I gave sound a 9/10 is because they are really awesome. You can grab them in your directory for free as well, and I have used the BGMs of this game before in my school projects as well. They have a wide range from classical to metal, and different maps invoke your feelings and really puts you into the world of Ragnarok with their music.Summary: Do NOT try to play this game alone, because you will probably ragequit due to all these bots who would KS you and helpdesk takes a super long time in looking and solving your queries. It can be a very fun game despite my critics, you should try this timeless game out before giving judgement of your own. Support the game if you like it, but I would highly doubt it because of poor customer service. Lastly, great way to kill time with your friends! I have hundreds of playing hours in this game and and made awesome lifelong friends - talking about a gamer for 4 good years in here.

												Seems they allow you to play three different versions of Ragnarok I on Steam. Classic, RePlay, and their newest edition. I've been a constant fan ever since they first started; I still remember when they had issues properly coding the 'Bash' move for swordsmen. I started playing their newest server, and though it stays reminiscent of what I'm used to, it seems to have molded for the future that MMOs in general have carved out for themselves. Instead of monthly fees, they have a cash shop. They make items for new interesting events thta I wish I could take place in, for say, the hat quests, but even though I am a high enough level to collect the items, I am not a high enough level to initiate the holiday event. I find that fairly irritating, personally. Holiday events should be available to all, and accomplished by those whom can, but it shouldn't be limited to those that spend hours and hours, if not possibly days in front of their computer trying to speed level in order to catch the event in time.But, that's just an event. The market has certainly changed. I remember when a 4-leaf clover costed millions because of what you had to go through in order to afford it. You would have to painstakingly kill hundreds or thousands of vine whipping stationary, but pretty mean monsters, pretty much giving up the hours you normally would use to level in order to find that one item. Now, they're being sold on market for 50k. Advanced drop rate? Or is it because they're so easily accessible now as a chance item in Giftboxes?I have more virtues than vices for this game still. There are things that have changed, things that I wish was still what I am used to, but I can always play the 'classic' server. I still love the community, and it's pretty social! It's still worth hours of fun, and some time I want to see them have cool achievements for Steam for me to accomplish. I highly recomend this game as a simple MMO that has been striving with a several thousand person community for about ten years. It was my first MMO, and it will probably be my last, at that. Why? Because every time I step away from it, one month later I get another random craving for it and end up running right back to this amazing community.

They make items for new interesting events thta I wish I could take place in, for say, the hat quests, but even though I am a high enough level to collect the items, I am not a high enough level to initiate the holiday event. The market has certainly changed. I remember when a 4-leaf clover costed millions because of what you had to go through in order to afford it. You would have to painstakingly kill hundreds or thousands of vine whipping stationary, but pretty mean monsters, pretty much giving up the hours you normally would use to level in order to find that one item. Now, they're being sold on market for 50k. Advanced drop rate? Or is it because they're so easily accessible now as a chance item in Giftboxes?I have more virtues than vices for this game still. There are things that have changed, things that I wish was still what I am used to, but I can always play the 'classic' server. I still love the community, and it's pretty social! 												I've been playing Ragnarok Online on and off since open beta, and no matter what game comes out, I keep finding myself coming back to this game.  Some of it's nostalgia for me, but the game definitely has a lot going for it.Pros:-The skill trees and class system are hard to beat-Cute art and a decent amount of items and whatnot to personalize your character (Though most of it is headgear)-The music is beyond phenomenal-It's been around for a long time and still gets content updates.-Some of the newer updates have been to make the game more user-friendly and easily accessible to newer players, such as an in-game navigation/search function for NPCs/Zones/Mobs, an in-game map with general level guides for each zone, and an amazing quest setup to make levelling worlds easier.-Events!  Loads of events, including monthly dungeons getting double exp/drops, Lunar Festival celebrations, and other holidays!-Rich, vibrant community-Game's so old, you could run it on a Windows 98 machine (I did)Cons:-Combat is very simplistic, based around a point and click system (Think Diablo 2)-The grind is real.  Killing monsters, expect to be happy if a monster gives .04% exp.  (Update!  The exp grind is much better!  Monsters *seem* to give more exp, especially in double exp dungeons)-Droprates are similarly bad.  There's a lot of headgear customization and cool items and whatnot, but most of the items of note are at 0.01% doprate or less, including ones from rarer, MVP monsters that require groups and coordination for a handful of drops.-The game is basically running dungeons and collecting hats.  There's more to it, but it's almost like garnishing.-No Auction House, and an entire Merchant Class dedicated to buying and selling items.-Very defined class roles (Don't expect Support classes to be able to solo).Now, the cons seem to outnumber the pros on this, but let me break down some of them, starting towards the bottom.In regards to MVPs, there are items called Dead Branches which spawn a random monster.  They *can* be MVPs, but they can be any monster in the game.  There are Bloody Branches which, I dunno how to get them on official servers but, are always MVPs (no guarantee if it's the one you want).  The game relies heavily on casting lots and hoping the RNG gods favor you this day.In regards to the Merchant Class (And I apologize for the big shpiel here), it's heavily support in its first form.  But the way the class tree works is, everyone starts as a Novice and at Job level 10 (Normally your base level is around 6 by then), you can switch to your first job, of which there are 6.  Then, when you reach level 40 at a minimum, you can upgrade to your second class (Each of the base jobs branches off into two separate paths).  Every Job level, however, you get a Skill point to spend, so it's highly adviseable to go to job level 50 (max in most cases) to squeeze out all the skill points you can.  Merchants upgrade into Blacksmiths, which can make weapons for folks.  And that's great!  Incredibly profitable, and very useful, as they can be a stopgap for those super high-end dropped weapons, PLUS they can be made elemental to take advantage of weaknesses and allow you to hit ghost property enemies.  OR, Blacksmiths can focus their stats on damage, and be a devastating damage dealer.  There's also Alchemist in the other branch, which is a pretty decent damage dealer too.  So there's light at the end of the tunnel for this support class.  Other ones?  Not necessarily.  Most of them are incredibly group reliant.Being group reliant isn't so bad, though!  Because the community's pretty awesome, on the whole.  Sure, there are bad eggs, but you'll find them in any game (plus you're likely to find a bunch of friendly folks here).Not having an Auction House lets you set whatever price you want, but people have to manually find your store you've set up with your character, and hopefully buy at your prices.  You have to be logged in the whole time for that, as well, and ONLY Merchant class characters (or above) can set up a stall.Also, when it comes to stats for characters, you get to completely decide them for yourself!  Which is good and bad, since it's really difficult to reset your stats.  I would advise finding a guide on the character you want to play, and how you want to play it, because you *could* make a high evasion/max attack speed Paladin, but it really wouldn't suit... anyone's needs well.There's the RL money component of the game, but this game is far from P2W.  There are a few incredibly useful things in the store, but you can get almost all of them in-game, or from other players.If those cons don't sound off-putting, I'd highly recommend giving it a try.  What do you have to lose?  It's fast, it's easy, it's free, much like pouring river water on your socks (But much more rewarding).

												One of the very first MMOs I've played in my entire life (it was pRO, Philippine RO, though). I first played back in 2004, when it was still a P2P and when Payon still had it's old map up. Everytime I feel like playing RO, I would buy either a P100 or P350 everytime, this was before I discovered private servers lol. While iRO used credit cards, pRO used prepaid cards. I was ecstatic and overjoyed when I found out it is now Free to Play. As a veteran player, I have enjoyed this game over the years. The community is friendly but not too mellow. Crazy things happen, and by "crazy" I mean wacky... in a good way, like having fun. I love the players here. They are friendly and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t rarely ever happens... only thing annoying now are the pesky bots roaming around the hunting maps (this never happened back then and don't worry, they don't appear in all maps). But they can be overlooked if you just simply ignore them, they don't KS or anything really.The gameplay itself is mediocre, considering it's a point-and-click, nothing too fancy. The sprites are adorable and the 3D background graphics are astonishing. The Eden and event quests are really fun to do. The tutorials teach you the basics really well and you get good stuff. There is a massive number of job class branches to choose from. (My favorite is the Assassin branch followed by the Wizard branch~) The merchant class is are something that is not so common in MMOs, so that's a plus too. There's also the guild siege or WoE (War of Emperium) which is really fun. The reasons why I enjoyed this game are the friendly community and the cute sprites. Some monsters are cute too and you can make them as pets. I love the idea that the entire game was based on the Norse Mythology.Truth be told, this is actually a game and depending on your preferences, you might either like it or don't like it. This is because there's no specific plot or any major storyline (there are quest lines that tell interesting stories though) and point-and-clicks can be boring at times. However, in spite of these, the events, quest lines, cute sprite, creative and realistic 3D maps, the nice visual effects when you use skills and magic, rebirths, and the merchant class are all the reasons why this is a pretty good MMO. I recommend this MMO to those who prefer the classic style of gaming and/or 2D games, because this is what Ragnarok Online gives. I grew up with clicky games which is why I came to love it.

												Nostalgia vs Reality - not a review~ Nostalgia got the better of me and seeing this available on Steam, I just had to install it. This was afterall, the first MMO I ever played back in 2000-2003 and also the first MMO community (twRO) with whom I had the good fortune to go adventuring with. Only five minutes into RO, I was entranced by the comfortable familiarity of it all. -/lazy insert everything I love about RO-Soon though, the nostalgic glow started to wear off...I missed the feeling of being a wide-eyed newbie, falling down and picking myself up again, bravely exploring a whole new world. I missed the community of twRO, I missed...I missed...Reality was, the RO of today is somewhat the same but different. Without going into details, some game mechanics are different, simply put. Anyways, my time on RO again after a decade (half of which was subsconsciously spent wishing that I was somehow still playing RO!) was deeply conflicting instead. Also, the awesome fun I had back then in RO also seemed to pale a little in comparison to the 'newer' fun I had in more recent MMOs; what a fickle mistress the human mind is when it comes to comparisons? The best of nostalgia can only happen when we look back at something and remember only the good but none of the bad and do no comparisons! My dear RO, I'll stick to remembering that lovely and familiar smile of yours, marvelling at the chemistry we had with each other and the good old times together with that community of twRO. :)I am not allowing myself to be stuck in the worse, for moving forward is as simple as trying something new: a relationship, creative projects, a new television show or game while holding fast to the firm knowledge that I was fortunate enough to have these fond memories of Ragnarok Online in my lifetime. tl;dr***Try it casually if you are new to RO (and to most modern 'action' MMOs) - but don't compare amongst them for RO can come across as antiquated; that won't bode well for the game nor for ya. I also had lag issues with this now and annoying chunky rubberbanding. ***Don't even try RO again, if you had played it before and especially if you had loved it to bits previously. There's no need to make new memories, your old ones of RO are precious enough and good enough forever.

Posted: July 9, 2015
												I admit, this game is a guilty pleasure of mine. I found it randomly on the internet when looking for games to play on my decade-old piece of scrap metal that was my last computer and, to my amazement, was pretty hooked. Back in the iRO days when I didn't have the money for a subscription I used to make multiple accounts just to play the 72-hour trial until I was told about private servers. Played those for a bit, found a few fun ones with a healthy population and then found out that WarpPortal had come out with RO for North America, free to play.Bursting with excitement I left my friends from the private servers to play this new completely legit, completely free server and...bots. Bots everywhere. Not once would I ever be around levelling and come across someone who isn't botting in one way or another, which had me feeling really down. Even when I played iRO my most favorite thing to do was explore the scenic places with my friends (the floating islands near Geffen, ruins in Morroc, Prontera's west gate garden) and hang out. So now that I had upgraded my computer I have long since left Ragnarok behind...Every now and then I get a rush of nostalgia that makes me want to play the game again and lo and behold I'm currently downloading it to play it again. Do I recommend this game to others? Absolutely. Botters aside, this game has an amazing soundtrack, neat places to explore and if you happen to come across a genuine player and you like each other, BE FRIENDS. Because you'll never know when another one like them will show up the next time you play.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												I have years of Ragnarok experience, but the vast majority has been on private servers. Even with this having been officially on Steam for a while, I still recommend finding a private server you like, instead. The grind isn't *quite* as bad as it used to be as you do at least get your early levels and can start playing around with your class' skills a little earlier, and there's more ways to get experience than simply killing stuff now...you can get quests to kill a specific amount of stuff. Huge improvement, there.Because of its slow progress, mid-to-late game grinding is best done in organized groups to improve the speed at which you kill mobs with coordination and drip-feeds of buffs and heals. Unfortunately, the official server's population is fairly volatile so finding these groups is going to be up in the air. Ragnarok has a somewhat archaic system in that by lategame if you're gonna be grinding alone, you might as well not bother - most mobs that give decent exp yields need at least a  minor degree of teamwork to take on, in part because few classes have the tools to manage aggro alone without running their MP batteries dry, so even those that can drop all the mobs after their blood spend a fortune on MP recovery without help.The heart and soul of Ragnarok still exists, but you should seek it elsewhere. The vanilla experience has too many flaws to let the game's strengths really shine.

												Oh god. What can I say about Ragnarok Online...? It's messy, outdated, unpolished, broken, and the economy has been absolutely CRUSHED by bots, which now likely outnumber players 8 to 1. And yet there is no other game in the world like it! I've gone back to this game more times that I care to confess, and it's because of just how damn unique it is. On paper, this game is outstanding! There's a crazy amount of content, the branching class system is unmatched, the specs each class can follow are wonderfully diverse, the soundtrack is whimsical, and everything about it is so damn enchanting! But then you find out everything costs a billion zeny, high level players troll outside of major cities to unleash boss monsters that kill everyone on the map, the UI is horribly outdated, there's no direction or guidance in the game, not every class spec is good or even viable, most classes need to follow very specific online builds to be good, and there are basically only 2 or 3 classes fit for PvP. Once upon a time, grinding was one of the absolute worst parts of the game. It would take actual months of straight grinding enemies just to level up once. One death costs you 1% of your experience, 5 months or more wasted, once you reached the mid 90s. Thankfully, that much has been fixed! Getting to level 40 alone may take you just a few days and its much less stressful. And while the game is still a broken mess, laggy as all hell, and outdated by over a decade, you may still find this game as enthralling as I have. The community is great, as well. There's an unbelievably vast number of online resources, from guides to metadata about every area, item, and monster--mostly due to the game data being cracked really early on, everything about the game is now available everywhere online! It's at least worth a run through level 40. And bring friends! Nothing livens up a busted system like a bunch of comrades to laugh and play with.There really is no other game in the world remotely like Ragnarok Online~

												I played this game a lot in college but over time it's lost it's appeal to me.  It's a beautiful game with lush environments and colorful sprites and monsters.  However, it gets repetitive and boring when you start leveling up in hours instead of minutes and the charm wears off.  For a purely casual RPG gamer side step this one.  This is also not a game you can play on your own which is bad for a solo player like me.  You will need friends or join a guild or you will never see all of the game's content.  To it's credit the combat is solid and the skill trees are good and leveling is satisfying.  I did though spend a lot of time trying to close out a dozen hot-key bars I accidentally opened.  All 100 different maps, charts, bars, screens have a macro to turn them on and off in your display and each one is explained briefly and only once in the 2+ hour tutorial section and good luck figuring out how to close them.   If you can spare the time to grind all the way to 100 twice, create another character to craft all your gear and potions, farm for card drops for weeks, and turn Ragnarok into essentially a full time job then go for it.  I am already tired of it and I'm not even level 30 so there's no way I have the patience for that.

Disregarding gameplay, RO is a game that will never expire: its art style with beautiful sprites is still fantastic and its environments while dated are done just well enough that they hold up well from the angle you play the game at. Many hours were burned through with this game and having not played it in two years, I'm sure many more will be, this time on Steam. Even after the game went free to play, it maintened everything that made it great. It's gone through so many changes but its core is still the same, and I can't recommend it enough to someone who wants to play a MMO that's satisfying and not completely generic.
